Median income is the amount which divides the income distribution into two equal groups, half having income above that amount, and half having income below that amount. Mean income (average) is the amount obtained by dividing the total aggregate income of a group by the number of units in that group. Median household income is a dollar amount that represents the dividing line in a household income distribution list. For example, if the median household income is $50,000, exactly one-half of the household incomes listed fall above this amount and exactly one-half fall below.

Meaning. Household income refers to the sum total of all income for members of the household over age 15, regardless of how many people live there or how they share the earnings. Median household income in a given year is the income for a household that's at the midpoint of all household incomes reported. It's not an average. Instead, it represents the middle income -- the point at which half of all households earn more, and half earn less.
